result.execSummary:
The defendant Kimber Leigh Burkhardt was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Manuf/Deliver Amphetamine(<=3g) [Modifiers: Habitual Criminality], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(e)1.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: IMPOSED & STAYED.  Concurrent to Trempealeau County Case No. 15CF136.

superMiscConds.notes: AODA and follow through with any treatment recommendations.

Defendant to pay court costs and DOC supervision fees.  Defendant to pay restitution as ordered.  Defendant is to comply with any treatment/programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and agent.

supervisions.notes: IMPOSED & STAYED.  Concurrent to Trempealeau County Case No. 15CF136.

Concurrent to Trempealeau County Case No. 15CF136.  In the event that the defendant is discharged from probation with outstanding financial obligations, the supervising agent SHALL notify the court 10 days prior to the revocation or discharge.  A civil judgment SHALL be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  5-12-2017:  Per correspondence from Judge Doyle - Court amends Repeater modifier from 939.62(1)(b) to 939.62(1)(c).

miscConds.notes: Defendant is to pay court costs and DOC supervision fees.
AODA and follow through with any treatment recommendations.
Defendant is to comply with any treatment/programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and agent.  Inability to pay restitution is not a sole reason to revoke probation.
